name: Alpine Style
description: Fast, lightweight, and self-sufficient climbing.
Climbers carry minimal gear, move quickly, and rely on natural shelters.
Common in the Alps, Rockies, and smaller peaks.
Example: Climbers attempting the Eiger’s North Face in one push.

name: Expedition Style
description: Used for high-altitude peaks like the Himalayas and Karakoram.
Involves establishing multiple camps, using porters or guides, and acclimatizing over weeks.
Heavy reliance on fixed ropes, oxygen, and logistical support.
Example: Traditional Everest and K2 expeditions.

name: Big Wall Climbing
description: Climbing massive rock faces, often over multiple days.
Requires hauling food, water, and sleeping on portaledges (hanging tents).
Often uses aid climbing techniques (placing gear to assist upward movement).
Example: El Capitan (Yosemite, USA).

name: Ice Climbing
description: Scaling frozen waterfalls, glaciers, or ice-covered rock faces.
Requires ice axes, crampons, and specialized protective gear.
Example: Ouray Ice Park (Colorado, USA).

name: Mixed Climbing
description: Combines rock and ice climbing techniques.
Often seen in Scottish Highlands, Canadian Rockies, and the Alps.
Requires crampons, ice tools, and rock protection.

name: Ski Mountaineering
description: Combines skiing with mountaineering, allowing rapid descents.
Requires avalanche safety knowledge and ski touring gear.
Example: Haute Route (France-Switzerland ski traverse).

name: High-Altitude Mountaineering
description: Climbing peaks above 7,000m (23,000 ft), often requiring oxygen.
Requires extensive acclimatization and technical climbing skills.
Example: Mount Everest (8,848m) and Denali (6,190m).

name: Technical Climbing
description: Climbing peaks above 7,000m (23,000 ft), often requiring oxygen.
includes difficult rock, ice, or mixed routes that require ropes, belays, and advanced climbing techniques.
Example: Matterhorn’s North Face (Switzerland).
